DataElement.preferredName: Laboratory Procedure Fasting Plasma Glucose Measurement Outcome Lab Upper Limit Normal Value
DataElement.preferredDefinition: the upper limit of normal of the medical procedure that involves testing a sample of blood for fasting glucose, a measurement essential diagnostic modality for different types of carbohydrate metabolism derangements taken following a period of abstaining from food.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Laboratory Procedure Fasting Plasma Glucose Measurement Outcome
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: information related to the result of the medical procedure that involves testing a sample of blood for fasting glucose, a measurement essential diagnostic modality for different types of carbohydrate metabolism derangements taken following a period of abstaining from food.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: A procedure for critical evaluation; a means of determining the presence, quality, or truth of something.

Concepts.definition: Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.

Property.preferredDefinition: Abstaining from food.:Glucose Plasma Concentration (GPC) measurement is an essential diagnostic modality for different types of carbohydrate metabolism derangements including diabetes mellitus. The disordered carbohydrate metabolism that underlies diabetes manifests as hyperglycemia. Plasma glucose concentrations in healthy individuals vary with age. Normal fasting plasma glucose intervals (in the morning after an overnight fast) in children are 3.3 - 5.6 mmol/L (60-100 mg/dL); adult range - 4.1- 5.9 mmol/L (74-106 mg/dL). GPCs are approximately 11% higher than whole blood if the hematocrit is normal. Glucose concentrations in heparinized plasma are reported to be 5% lower than in serum.:Outcome; a phenomenon that follows and is caused by some previous phenomenon.

Concepts.definition: Glucose Plasma Concentration (GPC) measurement is an essential diagnostic modality for different types of carbohydrate metabolism derangements including diabetes mellitus. The disordered carbohydrate metabolism that underlies diabetes manifests as hyperglycemia. Plasma glucose concentrations in healthy individuals vary with age. Normal fasting plasma glucose intervals (in the morning after an overnight fast) in children are 3.3 - 5.6 mmol/L (60-100 mg/dL); adult range - 4.1- 5.9 mmol/L (74-106 mg/dL). GPCs are approximately 11% higher than whole blood if the hematocrit is normal. Glucose concentrations in heparinized plasma are reported to be 5% lower than in serum.

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: trial-specific criteria that a patient must meet to be enrolled.

ValueDomain.preferredName: Milligrams per Deciliter Upper Limit Normal Value
ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: the upper limit of normal for a laboratory value in milligrams per deciliter.

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: The top value of the range of statistical characteristics that are supposed to represent accepted standard, non-pathological pattern for particular laboratory result or other quantitative parameter.:A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

Concepts.definition: The top value of the range of statistical characteristics that are supposed to represent accepted standard, non-pathological pattern for particular laboratory result or other quantitative parameter.
A numerical quantity measured or assigned or computed.

DataElement.origin: NCIC CRF:National Cancer Institute of Canada Case Report Form
